title: Reduce Team Cognitive Load by Standardising on PostgreSQL

context.description:
We need to make a decision about our database strategy for new services. The main options are to standardise on PostgreSQL, standardise on MongoDB, or allow teams to choose their own strategy.

What's driving this decision is the need to reduce team cognitive load, preserve strong ACID guarantees where required, and avoid unnecessary tool sprawl while still supporting fast delivery. At the same time, we have to deal with mixed workloads — some transaction-heavy, some document-oriented — and our teams don't all have the same level of database expertise.

This decision will impact team productivity, system reliability, and overall cost of ownership.
drivers: preserve strong ACID guarantees where required
teams don't all have the same level of database expertise

options.title: Standardise on PostgreSQL
options.description: PostgreSQL is a powerful, open-source relational database that supports ACID guarantees and has strong transactional support.

arguments.argument: May not be the best choice for document-oriented workloads

options.title: Standardise on MongoDB
options.description: MongoDB is a popular, open-source NoSQL database that supports flexible schema and high performance.

arguments.argument: May not support strong ACID guarantees

options.title: Allow teams to choose their own strategy
options.description: This option allows each team to select the best database solution for their specific needs, but may lead to tool sprawl and increased complexity.

arguments.argument: Teams can choose the best solution for their workload
May lead to unnecessary tool sprawl

decision.justification: This option best meets the need to preserve strong ACID guarantees where required, while also reducing team cognitive load and avoiding unnecessary tool sprawl.

consequences.consequence: May not be the best choice for document-oriented workloads
